did.unittitle: Delany mss.
did.abstract: The Delany mss., 1728-1760, consists of an anthology, a volume of original drawings, and the manuscript of Marianna by Mary (Granville) Delany, 1700-1788, artist and writer.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Mary (Granville) Delany, 1700-1788, was an English artist, letter-writer, and author. She was born at Coulston, Wiltshire to Colonel Bernard Granville and Mary Westcombe on May 14, 1700. After losing the opportunity to serve as a lady-in-waiting, Delany was married to Member of Parliament Alexander Pendarves in 1718 for political and financial reasons. Their marriage was an unhappy one, and she was widowed in 1725. After her first husband's death, Delany continued to cultivate her own interests and hobbies, including needlework, botany, drawing, and painting. On a trip to Ireland, she met her second husband, Dr. Patrick Delany, and they married in June 1743. After 25 years of marriage, she was widowed a second time when Dr. Delany died in 1768. Her second widowhood allowed Delany to hone her skills in botany and her talent for creating elaborate botanical decoupage. She is most well-known for these works of decoupage, which she called her "paper mosaicks," and for her lively and extensive correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The Delany mss., 1728-1760, consists of an anthology, a volume of original drawings, and the manuscript of the unpublished novel Marianna.

Delany wrote Marianna in 1759 to amuse herself and her sister. The novel is a "moral romance" that describes the misadventure of a young woman named Marianna who learns the value of obedience and respect for family.
Note on Indexing Term - "Art": The drawings are mounted in a bound scrapbook which is dated 1732-1760.

did.unittitle: A Young Lady being desir'd to write a Copy of verses, she ask'd upon what, a Boy in Company answer'd What should she write on but Paper? On which she immediately writ the following Lines. [signed] Mrs. Pilkington (nine octosyllabic couplets, beginning "O spotless paper, Fair and White")
The Petition of the Birds by the author of the foregoing Verses to her Husband (sixteen octosyllabic couplets, "Ah Shepherd, gentle Shepherd, spare")

Writ by a Lady at the request of Some of her Friends who desired she would write her Epitaph, and such a Character as she would willingly leave behind her when she dyed (seven decasyllabic couplets, "When Purer Skies recal the Kinder Ray")
The Epitaph (eight decasyllabic couplets, "As she was once, few of her Sex you'll see")
On the Birth Day of a Young Lady. By H: H: [in a different hand now] Mrs. Hariott Dunch afterwards Dutchess of Manchester (31 octosyllabic couplets, "On Amber Clouds the other day")
Written Impromptu to a Lady knotting.-- (four octosyllabic couplets, "The Subtle Nett when Vulcan Wove")
An Epitaph occasion'd by the Death of a young Lady, and writ by her Brother (ten decasyllabic couplets, "Reader attend:--and if thine eye let fall")

An Epistle to the Honourable Henry Hervey Esq. desiring him to sit for his Picture. Mr. Hervey inscrib'd very neatly with his own Hand a Piece of Silver for the Author, with his own Name in a Cypher and this motto under Amitie sans Feinte [signed] Dr. Greville (34 decasyllabic couplets, two triplets, "Oh Hervey, by no Merit of my own")
Written Impromptu to a Lady Stung by a Bee (one stanza ABABCDCD, "To heal the wound a Bee had made")

Verses to the Memory of John Snell Esq late Representatives in Parliament for the City of Gloucester address'd to Charles Yate Esq his dearest Friend and at that time a Patient of the Authors [signed] Doctor Grevile 1726 (42 decasyllabic couplets, "In vain oh Yate, my grief I wou'd restrain")
An Epitaph on two Lovers That were Burn't to Death by Lightning (three decasyllabic couplets, "Tho' these two Lovers were destroyed by Fire")
An Epistle From a Young Lady to her Lover (three stanzas ABAB, "Thy vain Pursuit fond youth give o'er")
The Answer [signed] H: H: (three stanzas ABAB, "Thy vain advise Coy Maid give o'er")
The Indian Philosopher (ten stanzas AABCCB, "Why shou'd our Joys transform to Pain")

In praise of the tooth ach, written at the Command of a Young Lady upon her having cu'd the author of a fit of it [signed] The Revd. Mr. Newton of glouster (21 decasyllabic couplets, "Long since the muse's have been taught to raise")
Writt by a Lady in Cook upon Littleton, to her Brother [signed] Mrs. Spencer Cowper (seven decasyllabic couplets, "Oh thou who Labourest in this Rugged mine")
The Plan of the following Poem [Pompey and Flora, my title] (nine-line prose argument, followed by 45 decasyllabic couplets, six triplets, "E'er Death these closing Eyes for ever shade")
Writ by Mrs. Moulsworth when she was very ill and sent to her Husband (eleven decasyllabic couplets, "Thou who doest all my Worldly thoughts Imploy")
To a Young Lady from her Friend (52 decasyllabic couplets, four triplets, "Thou to whose will the Muse obsequious pays")

[untitled] The following lines were written in a Young Lady's book call'd, A Demonstration of the Existence and Attributes of God (five decasyllabic couplets, "If not convinc'd Oh Cambray by thy Book")
An Essay on Friendship (prose, ending with one stanza ABCB, "But I forbear my vain attempt")
A Dialogue between the Poet and his Friend [signed] first Lord Hervey (112 decasyllabic couplets, four triplets, "Poet--Why wears my pensive Friend that gloomy Brow")
Monimia to Lothario [signed] Lord Hervey (92 decasyllabic couplets, three triplets, "Since Language never can describe my pain")
The Resolution (seventeen seven-syllable couplets, one triplet, "Let the Prude--or let the Saint")
The Change (twelve seven-syllable couplets, "Sweet Enslaver--can you tell")
The Change Continued (eighteen seven-syllable couplets, one triplet, three decasyllabic couplets--one imperfect, "ease is Languid, low and Base")
Upon a Young Ladys Lodging being Calld Unpleasant (four seven-syllable couplets, "Where is the unpleasant Place")
Upon Thought, by A Lady (eight stanzas ABAB, "There's many dangers we may 'Scape")
On the foregoing Verses address'd to a friend by a Lady (five stanzas ABAB, "'Tis true reflection often brings")
Me only chance can kill thou frailer [?] creature [?] / May dye like me by chance, but must by Nature [these two lines along on the page]
The Parson's Case In Imitation of Martial (20 octosyllabic couplets, "That you, Parthenius like a Stoick")
Two Ladies having made an agreement to Live a Recluse Life togather, one of them altering her Opinion sent this Recantation the next Morning (four stanzas AABCCB, "All Railery Apart")
A Riddle Addressd to the Authors Sister (12 octosyllabic couplets, "By Nature Wild in Desarts bred")
Solution to the Riddle, addressed to the author (six octosyllabic couplets, "Ah! Lovely Rose, in Desarts bred")
Lady Mary Wortleys Answer to a Friend (six decasyllabic couplets, "You little know the Heart which you advise")
To a Young Lady who desired to know her Fortune (eleven 11- and 12-syllable couplets, "Forbear my Dear Nympth with a Fruitless desire")
Stilts (13 stanzas, mostly ABCB, "Leaving the grammer for his Play")
To the Dean of St. Patricks on his Birth-day; by Dr. Delany (11 decasyllabic couplets, "How long with Faith shall every Virtue fail")
Epitaph on Miss A: Cook [signed] J. [or I.] N. (new hand, three decasyllabic couplets, "Here sleeps that Virgin Saint, to whom by Heaven")
A: Letter to Mrs. T[?]: H. with the foregoing Verses (prose, four pages)
Verses wrote on the Window of Mr. Millers Thatch'd House by Mr. Merrick-- (two stanzas AABCCB, "Stay Passenger & tho' within")
To Stella (16 stanzas ABAB, "No more my Stella to the sighing shades")
To the Pearl--Mrs. D____ by Dr D____ on ye Pearl Fountain at Calwich-- 21st Sep.r 1743 (new hand, 20 octosyllabic couplets, "Thou purest source, of noblest birth")
The Nurse by Mrs. C____e (four stanzas ABABCC, "How oft when Maladies attack us sore")
Lines by Sr. Edwd Boynton on George Marquiss of Tweddale-- (three decasyllabic couplets, "'Twas a short Life, as that to Roses fix'd")
Addition to the Revd. Mr. W. Cooke (four decasyllabic couplets, "But as when warmer Suns & milder Skies")

Stanzas Sacred to the Memory of the Right Honourable The Lady Grace Hay Whose endearing Sweetness of Disposition and Innocent Sensibility of Heart Joined to strong Sense & a discerning Judgement Render'd her equally lamented & esteemed (eight stanzas ABAB, "Say! Ye great Guardian Angels, who convey")
An Ode to Mr Lyttelton on his Marriage. No Tho. Lord Lyttelton 1773--- (11 stanzas ABAB, "Will thou to Love new Altars raise")
Sonnet by Mr Sheridan (three stanzas ABAB, "Cherub of Heaven! That from thy secret Stand")

A new-born Daughter of Sr. Tho. Pope's was presented to King James wth ye following Verses in her Hand, which as they pleased the King, 'tis hoped will not displease the Reader [signed] (Fuller's Worthies) (three stanzas: 1st and 2nd four lines with "And yet she is a Pope" as refrain; 3rd stanza five lines--same refrain, "See this little Mistress here." A separated concluding couplet: "A female Pope! you'll say a second Joan,/ No, sure she is Pope Innocent or none.")
On the Death of Sr. Albertus and Lady Morton (one decasyllabic couplet, "He first deceas'd--she, for a little, try'd")
On two Twin Sisters (two stanzas ABAB, "Fair Marble, tell to future Days")

By Mrs Delany in ye 83d year of her age when ye failure of her Eyes prevented Her going on with her mosaick Flower Work (new hand, ten--mainly--octosyllabic couplets, "The time is come, I can no more")
Mrs Delany on ye Dss of Portland (new hand, four decasyllabic couplets, "O' Time whose Steady unremiting Pace")
